Some ramblings about Twitter

So… many… smart… people… have already written about Twitter and how to fix it. I’ve avoided throwing my hat in the ring because 1) What the hell do I know? And 2) I believe that nobody has thought more about the problem than Twitter employees. But, I found myself wanting to speak out amidst all of the recent buyout chatter, its Q3 earnings, and Jack’s one-year anniversary as CEO; so here we go.

Quick disclaimer: I believe the core product is great. This post mostly discusses concepts beyond features and more on structural issues that I perceive with the company.

1. Reduce size to move faster

Twitter was born out of the right constraints, yet ironically the company is too bloated and held back by internal politics and bureaucracy.

It’s a real problem because no one is thinking more deeply about Twitter than the product managers and engineers working on the ground every single day. There are plenty of capable and loyal individuals that just want to get shit done, but I get the sense that:

  1. Teams don’t feel empowered enough (or close enough to those in power) to implement big changes.
  2. Teams are too siloed and unable to collaborate effectively. From what I’ve heard, the “Home timeline” and the “Moments” teams are on different coasts (SF and NYC). They should be within earshot.

In my time at companies like Google and Square, I realized that all organizations form antibodies over time. They strive to maintain the status quo and prevent drastic change, generally out of fear of losing what made the company great in the first place. It can be very hard, as an intrepid employee who wishes to instigate meaningful change, to cut through these defenses, and failing to do so quickly leads to low morale.

My gut feeling is Twitter has built up an unhealthy amount of antibodies, formed over the course of its checkered past, that need to be excised from the organization. The leadership team must take a tough look at the entire staff through this lens, identify employees who have a tendency to “open more doors than they close,” and immediately part ways with them. Keep the doers, ditch the pontificators — that includes the leadership team being introspective with itself too.

As Sergey Brin once said, “scarcity breeds clarity.” And a scarcity of resources could be a key constraint for the company to focus on what matters.

2. Go private

Wall Street is a huge distraction to the company and its employees. If Twitter wants to grow its base, it needs to focus on the product. And how can it do that with Wall Street always breathing down its neck?

I am far from an expert on how this would work, what it would mean in practice fiscally, or what it would do for Twitter’s ability to hire talent; but I believe it would be a massive weight off of the blue bird’s shoulders. The goal here is to free them up to make the bets that they want to without having to answer to anyone else except themselves.

And for those who would still want to join Twitter will more likely be true believers in the mission. Those are the type of people Twitter needs.

3. Retire the Periscope brand, fold it into Twitter

Periscope, while a gorgeous app, is not a runaway hit brand like Vine is (was), even if that only lasted a hot minute. Instagram all but put an end to it with the inclusion of video and Facebook is poised to do the same with FB Live. Twitter needs to act fast and focus on its unique strengths (its network model).

Twitter should sunset the standalone Periscope consumer app (though it may stand as a branded tool for creators). The fact that Meerkat fizzled out isn’t because Periscope ate it’s lunch (well, it sort of is), it’s because there wasn’t a real social need. Otherwise it could have been successful as a number two (see Lyft). Twitter saved Periscope from the same demise by throwing its weight behind it and supporting it in the core product. I’m sorry, but nobody has time to stop what they’re doing and watch their friend stream their puppy playing at the beach over and over again.

Periscope, at its best, is when a small set of individuals have visible access to an major event (e.g., a burning building in your local neighborhood). But these events are few and far between, and requiring a separate app does the concept a disservice. What if you find yourself in front of a burning building, but haven’t download Periscope? People should think Twitter and Twitter alone.

Meanwhile, it’s great that Twitter made Periscope available directly in the timeline itself, but they should make “go live” an option in its app, as simple as clicking a button. It then does everything in its power to make that available, such as to your followers, those in your geographical location, etc.

For what it’s worth, Periscope has been on a downward trend this year (according to App Annie ranks), and I think it’s because the average person doesn’t find value in the app itself. It’s time to reign it in and make video great again.

Disclaimer: I say this with all of the love in my heart because I have dear friends that work on Periscope. They are amazing and deserve to have their work mean the most it can. I hope I’m wrong and whatever Twitter’s strategy is here, is the right one.

4. Redefine what “Live” means on Twitter

Bear with me because this is one is a bit more abstract.

According to Jack, Twitter is “live.” But the inherent problem with live content is that it’s synchronous, and we live in an ever-increasingly asynchronous world. Synchronous content works when it’s newsworthy, highly relevant to an individual, or extremely compelling. This is why networks like HBO and Netflix spend billions on premium content. It costs big $$$ to manufacture undivided attention of a massive audience for an extended period.

One of Twitter’s core strengths is that you can jump in and get “caught up” any time on the most recent happenings in the world. And that brings me to my hypothesis:

Twitter has the capability to redefine live, where live means being “in the moment,” even if its actually in the past.

So what does that even mean? Well, I missed yesterday’s Warrior’s game one, where they lost handily to the Spurs. Why can’t I relive that through many different vantage points directly in Twitter? Twitter has the data; it’s just not grouped and surfaced in that way.

Text is the most widely used and one of the oldest mediums on the planet. It’s not going anywhere any time soon, and its Twitter’s primary medium. Therefore, it has a unique opportunity to capture all of this commentary and discussion and serve it for years and years to come. Imagine if when you were reading a book about the Civil War or the Holocaust in history, you could go back and see all of the commentary, photos, videos (from both sides) that lead up to these events. You could completely immerse yourself and relive the experience. Twitter can (and should) make this available a hundred years from now for the 2016 Presidential Race, regardless of the outcome on November 8th.

In short, I believe the company should focus less on striking all of these live deals that are already available on primetime television (NFL, Presidential Debates, etc) that are not really expanding their base, and instead focus on a unique offering that only Twitter can provide: the ability to immerse myself in an event, regardless if its happening now or not.

5. Double down on Moments

Moments is effectively the “tabloid” version of Twitter, which is perfect for new and casual users. It’s a killer app built on top of the tweet firehose. However, it’s buried in the app and feels “bolted on.” Furthermore, it’s hardly evolved since its launch, short of the ability to create moments with the web version of the product, which is a fine first step — but you need to move faster because Moments could be Twitter’s version of Google Reader (which was awesome).

As an avid Twitter user, I love moments. I go there every day to get a birds-eye view (no pun) of what’s happening in the world right now. It spans the emotional gamut, with everything from comedy to tragedy. It also gives users another reason to participate in the global conversations, have their tweets featured and be “discovered.”

Sadly, many people don’t even know it exists. I showed and explained Moments to some friends that are self-proclaimed “Twitter lurkers,” but had no clue what Moments was. They were instantly hooked some drew a comparison to “Discover” in Snapchat or a visual RSS aggregator.

PS. Moments is a perfect location to surface live events as they’re happening. When the first NFL game was aired on Twitter, it was naturally the first place I went to find it, but didn’t.

6. Crack the social search problem

Twitter search has so much potential to be more than it is today. Everyone knows how to use search thanks to Google, who figured out how to magically search the entire open web over 15 years ago. Why shouldn’t Twitter aim to do the same for its own content? Based on my anecdotal experience, many people believe that Twitter search is only for hashtags. For example, why can’t I search “best TVs” on Twitter and immediately find relevant and compelling articles that were tweeted about TVs and the discussion around these items? In fact, why can’t I just search “TVs” and get halfway decent results? Try it yourself.

Search is arguably one of the most powerful features for a new user. They will come to Twitter for the first time, and if they don’t immediately see content relevant to them, will try and search for it. If that doesn’t produce at least a somewhat relevant experience, then you’ve lost them.

7. Automagically group tweets by topic

I often scroll through my feed and see the same topic being discussed by many different people. For example, a large amount of my feed right now is about the Microsoft’s Surface Studio announcement. But, it’s mixed with election tweets, random tweets from people I follow, and ads. That’s a bad experience. Allow me to “pivot” on any given tweet into a stream of tweets about that same topic, and I don’t mean hashtag search #SurfaceStudio or #Trump. Twitter should do more to “intelligently group” similar tweets in a way that allows me to experience what’s happening about that topic.

8. Other incremental core product enhancements

I believe the core product is fucking fine, but wanted to add a few incremental improvements that I think might make the overall experience better.

  • Add read receipts. Every tweet should tell you who has seen the tweet. This gives further insight into your tweets and how they resonate with your audience. There are many ways to implement this, for example, if you have a tweet on your screen for longer than a second, that counts as a “read.” People need to know who is reading their content, not just liking or clicking through it.
  • Improve conversation readability. It is way too hard to follow a conversation between two people, let alone three or more. Twitter has all of the data it needs to surface a UI that is far more capable of presenting a conversation than is done today. If Reddit can manage N-levels of depth in its conversations, Twitter can do it too.
  • Suggest hashtags on compose. While writing a post on a particular topic, it wouldn’t be too hard for Twitter to offer hashtags relevant to that topic that you can quickly “add” to your tweet. Medium does this with tags, and it works quite well for them. There’s nothing worse than posting a tweet about a topic and forgetting (or never knowing there was) a hashtag that could have been added to give your tweet more exposure.

And a few words on Safety

I want to recognize that this post does not address Twitter’s bullying/abuse issues. Twitter is an open and free network that anyone can join and the point is such that any person in the world can spread a thought whose impact is directly proportional to the merit and timeliness of the idea.

Twitter’s future as a global platform hinges on the ability for real people to have open and honest discourse without an underlying fear of unexpected retribution or retaliation. I don’t know how to solve that completely, and I’m not even sure the technology or enforceable policy exists, but Twitter should continue to work hard at these problems, even if it means making drastic policy changes along the way.

In conclusion

That was a short list of things that I feel are important to Twitter. And there’s no shortage of other ideas that could make the experience incrementally better (not stickers!), but I think the first step is to get out from under scrutiny and do what it does best: create the right constraints.

Twitter needs to reign itself in and focus on its core product, making it an approachable, yet infinitely deep experience. Jack and the leadership team should obsess over the details of the core product and embolden the teams to move as fast and as deliberately as possible.

Feel free to follow me on Twitter @davidbyttow

You should subscribe to my email newsletter: newsletter.davidbyttow.com

By David Byttow on October 26, 2016.

posts.html:
Be Succinct.

Especially In Writing.

Be Succinct.

Especially In Writing.

Use “I” and “Me” less.
These two words are terrible. They make you sound weak and they make you write passive verbs. Activate your verbs by removing these pronouns.

For example:
“I don’t think this is a good idea” vs. “This is not a good idea.”

Tell me which is stronger? Which is easier to read and which is better at getting the point across? In my opinion, the second, but your mileage may vary.

“But, David, this makes me sound like a huge jerk,” you say. If you’re really worried, then put a smiley at the end of the sentence. But you shouldn’t be because your reader will thank you.

Edit. Then edit again.
Shorter messages are better. You can always edit your sentences down. Read some Hemingway; the guy knows how to write a short sentence. Here’s some homework, the next time you respond to an email from a colleague or coworker, go back and try to cut out as many words as possible; you’ll be surprised at the results. Not only will it be more succinct, it will read like you mean it.

Be vigorous, but positive.
When I write an email, I find it better to be as vigorous yet positive as possible. This maximizes your point for the reader. Being vigorous induces and promotes focus for the reader, but remaining positive is a reminder that you are constructive.

To give an example, here’s an early draft of something I wrote in response to an email. Here’s the message I received:

Hi David,
Can you bring back the garage opener sometime next week?
Thank you and have a nice weekend!

And here’s my original draft response:

“Of course, I’m sorry for the delay. I meant to bring it back on Sunday but was late for a 8:30AM flight. I will be back next week and return it sometime then, probably Monday. Thanks!”

Then edited it down to:

Absolutely. Sorry for the delay. Had to run out of town.

The original message is redundant. For starters, the sender is already asking to return the item back next week, there’s no reason for me to repeat it. All I need to basically say is yes, apologize and a brief explanation why I’m late.

Actually, now that I look at this, the best response would have been:

Yes.

And I should bring it back on Monday.

By David Byttow on May 5, 2013.

Bold — Make your words stand out.

The best ideas can come from anywhere, especially within your company. Everyone has opinions, yet they often go unshared — we want to solve…

Bold — Make your words stand out.

The best ideas can come from anywhere, especially within your company. Everyone has opinions, yet they often go unshared — we want to solve that problem.

Bold aims to provide the best experience for reading and writing long-form content at work so that your best ideas can be heard.

How? First, we want to make your words beautiful. Next, we want to help you make your words clear and concise — making it easier to digest and understand. Finally, we’ll help you make your words heard — sharing a post and receiving feedback should be easy.

We want to encourage everyone to write more and share ideas more freely in their company by creating the best canvas to communicate them.

We’re still deep in the process of shaping Bold and want your feedback. We’ll be giving access to people in the coming weeks, so add your email here: https://bold.io/post/make-your-words-stand-out-udvqaw

By David Byttow on June 7, 2016.

posts.html:
Master of His Craft

The Builder

Master of His Craft

The Builder

Mark Byttow is an artist and a master of his craft. I call him a builder.

Everyone builds. Whether it be a model car, an app, or a family. To me, building is the simple act of creating something from nothing.

At a very young age, my father built model airplanes and cars. By his early teenage years, began flying radio-controlled aircraft with other hobbyists that were four times his age. Rather than cultivating a social life, he spent most of time in his basement workspace. He was focused, determined and enjoyed every minute of it.

And building wasn’t only a hobby, it became his career. Today, with a little wood and a lot of creativity, he builds works of art that are beautiful, practical, and timeless. They must be both aesthetically pleasing and serve a functional purpose every day for years.

His business, Byttow Woodworking, a high-end, custom cabinetry business, has been a labor of love for over 30 years of his life, after taking it over from his father, Norman Byttow. I’ve never known him to do anything else professionally.

Malcolm Gladwell claims the key to success in any field is, to a large extent, a matter of practicing a specific task for a total of around 10,000 hours. With some quick back of the envelope math, my dad has easily spent well over 100,000 hours honing his craft. That is over 11 years straight spent building. Or, 1/5 of his life, which is a lot considering 1/3 of our lives are spent sleeping.

Spend two minutes with Mark Byttow, and you will know that you have met someone good, honest, and pure in his intentions. He is young at heart, with a child-like innocence that those close to him cannot help but love to be around.

Although he sometimes refers to himself as “The Big Arm” or “Tower of Power,” he is a gentle giant. Standing 6'3" tall with blond hair, blue eyes, and a very muscular physique; but not because he spends his time at the gym. My dad has a very rare, genetic neuromuscular disease, called myotonia congenita.

Luckily, he has a variation that makes him capable of living a normal life. The upside is that it has granted him the type of physique that many people spend years cultivating at the gym. The primary downside, however, is that he lacks the ability to activate his fast-twitch muscles without first “warming them up”. His first few steps are reminiscent of Frankenstein’s stiff-legged walk. But, he quickly settles into a standard gait. Most people never notice, and he does a great job of covering it up, but it prevented him from being involved in sports as a child. Perhaps this has played into his childhood spent building models and toys.

Needless to say, my father has been one of the biggest inspirations of my life. He may not understand how to build software, but he respects the craft and understands that it too, is a form of building that is both an art and a science.

I moved out to California from Chicago (see Four Steps to Google, Without a Degree), so nearly all of my family is there, including my dad. But we talk often, and he asks tons of questions about what is going on in my life; he never talks about himself.

My dad is very proud of my accomplishments in life. Nevertheless, most of my motivation and ambition comes from an inner urge to prove that I too, am a master of my craft. Perhaps it’s some sort of self-seeded guilt for not taking over the family business or because I didn’t finish college as he would have liked me too. Maybe it’s because I feel like I’m not as adept at my profession as he is at his. I’m not sure, but it doesn’t really matter because it fuels my burning desire to make him proud, which has showed no signs of slowing down.

He has always reminded me: “Time wasted is time lost forever.” He keeps me honest and deliberate with my intentions. He also taught me that if it doesn’t feel right, it’s not right. Or, in his words, “when in doubt, go without.”

Dad, thank you for the support you have given me over the years. Especially for watching Charlie while I work on my new venture. All I can say is, if my children grow up seeing me as I do you, I’ll know I have succeeded as a parent. I love you.

P.S. Mom, thank you and I love you too. :-)

Passwords Are Broken, a Temporary Fix.

Passwords Are Broken, a Temporary Fix.

Passwords are broken, but unfortunately necessary. In this article, I explain how I keep all of my accounts secure by creating strong, unique AND memorable passwords.

Signing in to an account is all about proving your identity. And that can be accomplished in three primary ways:

  1. Something you know. This is the most common, and what a password effectively represents. This is the cheapest solution.
  2. Something you have. In the real world, this is a physical key or a fob. In the digital world, this is often represented by your mobile phone.
  3. Something you are. This is rare, but a common example is a fingerprint or retina scan. Although extremely secure (except in the future that is Minority Report), it’s also the most intrusive and expensive solution and doesn’t really work in the digital world.

Given the rarity of #3, let’s disregard.

That leaves something you know and something you have. Choosing between the two, the former is more secure because it’s harder to lose or misplace something you know. But the two combined, is extremely secure. This is known as “two-factor authentication,” or 2F in short. Gmail offers this and you should enable it immediately. That brings me to my first point.

Protect your email account at all costs.
This is is a single point of failure. Most services don’t offer 2F auth and rely on you creating a password. If you forget that password, the service will likely allow you to reset it via your email address. So if you’re email address is compromised, you’re potentially in for a world of hurt. Make your email password strong and enable 2F authentication.

Don’t share passwords across accounts.
Good folks often use the same password for random-new-social-app-they-just-read-about-on-TechCrunch that they use for their most critical services. Do you really trust the junior developer implementing account creation to encrypt and protect your password in their datastore? Or to even prioritize it? Don’t. If someone gets that password and then attempts to re-use it on another service that you shared it with, you’ve been compromised. And oh-dear-god please never re-use your primary email password.

Develop your own password generation algorithm.
So, your passwords should be strong AND unique, but how will you remember them? There exist solutions to this, such as 1Password, which believes that the most secure password is one that you can’t remember. But, once again, this is a potential single point of failure.

Instead, what I do is create a tiny algorithm for generating passwords. For example, say you’re creating a password for two services: Instagram and Vine.
Instagram: Qfjpin0109$
Vine: Qfjpvi0109$

In isolation, these look pretty secure. They’re broken up in the following way:
Qfjp: Random (or not!) string of letters.
in: First two letters of the service name.
0109: Someone significant’s birthday.
$: Punctuation character (if allowed).

Of course, given two of these passwords, it’s likely pretty easy for someone to deduce the pattern. But you can take this as far as you like. For example, perhaps if the service ends in a vowel, you swap the random letters and the numbers. Or, instead of the first two letters of the service name, you use the first letter + 1 (so, j instead of i).

The point is, given only a couple chunks of information to remember (4 letters and a couple rules), you can create a unique and strong password for each service.

Oh, and please go enable two-factor authentication for your email accounts.

By David Byttow on July 17, 2013.

Let go or be dragged?

A few days ago, I sat down over coffee with the founder of an interesting company. Typically, the founders I meet with are interested in…

Let go or be dragged?

A few days ago, I sat down over coffee with the founder of an interesting company. Typically, the founders I meet with are interested in investor introductions, market validation, or want to discuss product and engineering challenges (which I love).

But this person sought my advice on whether or not shutting down his year-old company was the right thing to do.

Before meeting, I did a little research, and at first glance the company and product seemed very viable. There was a clear market, and I felt they could find product fit pretty easily, which is probably how they were able to drum up a significant amount of funding.

I won’t go into the details of exactly why he felt it might be best to wind down, but as soon as we sat down to chat I wanted to see if shutting down his company is what he felt he should do or must do, there’s a big difference. Then I decided to share a couple important high-level realizations that I had when my team and I shut down Secret.

  1. Let go or be dragged. This is an adage that someone said to me (I wish I could remember who!) and resonated with me before making the decision to wind down my company. When we become deeply attached to a particular outcome, which may not seem achievable, we can enter into the mentality of being the victim, lose control and forfeit the power of making our own choices. This is a downward spiral and requires a level of self-awareness to figure out if we’re in this state. If so, then deciding to let go can be the first step toward regaining control of our situation.
  2. Tough things are harder to envision than they are to endure. Once the decision was made and we took the correct steps to wind down the company, it didn’t hurt as much as I had anticipated because it felt like the right thing to do. This is human. I believe that if you are honest and true in your intentions, and with those around you (employees, investors, users), then you can control your narrative and those that matter will have your back.

Of course there are very empirical factors to weigh when it comes to evaluating whether or not to make a decision like shutting down a company, but as the CEO or founder, that decision starts with you and these two points really helped me.

And if that doesn’t help, there’s always lessons learned from Fight Club.

“It’s only after we’ve lost everything that we’re free to do anything.”
-Tyler Durden

David Mark Byttow

posts.html:
“I Got It!”

Wait, no I don’t.

“I Got It!”

Wait, no I don’t.

Vegas. Some friends and I decided to go for the weekend naturally. This time the brilliant idea was to “suit up” and hit the clubs. Second club on the list was Tryst to be headlined by Skrillex.

We shelled out for a private table on the water walkway, which happens to be the only path up to the stage. Skrillex would need to walk past us to get to his MacBook Pro.

Before the main show began I overheard Jennifer, a girl in our group, begging my friend AJ to procure her a photo with the dubstep master. Always willing to impress, AJ decided to make this happen by shouting Skrillex’s real name (Sonny) as he walked by and asking for a photo with the two of them. I didn’t think this plan would work, but it was worth a shot.

As he walked by, sure enough, AJ starts to shout “Sonny! Sonny! Can we get a photo?” While being ushered by two large bodyguards, Sonny stops, turns around and agrees to one photo.

Unfortunately for my friends, they handed me the phone. By then, I probably was roughly 3-4 drinks in and feeling pretty good. The camera was in selfie (front-facing) mode. Among the chaos, I tried and failed to change the camera mode and snapped the photo. AJ quickly responded with “The flash was off, did you get it?” to which I famously replied in my finest Chicago accent “I got it!”

Nope. I didn’t. And as Skrillex ran off to take the stage and they reviewed the photo, the look of shock and disappointment that came over Jennifer’s face when she saw my awkward self-shot instead of her and Skrillex was something I will never forget.

By David Byttow on May 5, 2013.

posts.html:
The fastest way to test a business idea

TL;DR:

The fastest way to test a business idea

TL;DR:

  • Build a simple web app with a conversion funnel (e.g., email signup)
  • Use a service like zeit.co to spin it up quickly
  • Test your market by running ads via Adwords or FB or word-of-mouth
  • Do not “launch” it publicly on places like Product Hunt :)
  • Example: https://usestart.com

As a developers in tech, we constantly encounter new problems to be solved that might make good businesses.

Not many years ago, it was actually fairly involved to do things like setup a streaming web socket API (Pusher), or implement real-time search (Algolia), or implement a synchronizing data storage layer (Firebase). These businesses stemmed out of common problems that developers faced.

And while there are always new problems to be solved as technology progresses, it’s widely accepted and generally smart to test your theories against the market before committing too much of your time to it.

Start

For example, I recently had the idea with a colleague to build a service that made user signups incredibly easy. At first, I was incredibly excited about the concept, so we took a few hours out of a couple days to quickly launch and test the theory with ads. After spending a few hundred dollars on ads to get early feedback, we determined that the conversion and interest wasn’t strong enough to move forward. At that point, we felt confident that the idea either needed to evolve or we should shelve it for now. We chose the latter.

Here’s the site we tested: https://usestart.com

We built the site with React and Node.js, bought the domain and configured it with Zeit DNS, and deployed it with Zeit now, which was a delight. Our “backend” was just a Mailchimp email list. All of this was put together in less than 8 hours with almost no money out of pocket. Here’s the code: https://github.com/simplethingsllc/start

For anyone with a business idea that they’re considering pursuing, I highly recommend this strategy as a first step.

posts.html:
Google+ is the Six Flags of Social Networks.

Google+ is the Six Flags of Social Networks.

Disclaimer: I worked on Google+ for two years, as technical lead for the +1 Button and several other key products within Google+.

Google+ looks amazing. If you haven’t played with it recently, try it out. The UI is fluid, animates like a Nintendo game and the content is extremely legible.

But it’s too damn complex.

Visual design alone won’t directly move the needle for Google+. It will push Facebook (and others) to up their game in the design department.

Here are some of the “core” features of Google+. It has a content stream, a what’s hot stream, curated circles, rich profiles, photos, communities, events, hangouts, notifications, chat, non-people pages, local businesses, games (soon to be discontinued), instant upload, and so on.

In my opinion, the product needs two things before it should consider how to find its place in an already crowded social market:

  1. Remove features. There’s just too much to do in Google+. It’s quickly becoming the Six Flags of social networks. Something normal people do maybe once or twice a year.
  2. Create constraints. Good designers have wised up to the fact that less is more and simplicity is king. Constraints enable creativity. What is the “haiku” of Google+?

Google+ is an amazing technical achievement on almost all fronts. And there are quite a few gems hidden within Google+ itself, but with everything else going on, those gems are simply lost in the rough.

By David Byttow on May 21, 2013.

A new data storage solution

There are so many storage solutions available to developers. Analysis paralysis often hits when trying to figure out what is going to work best for you. 

The typical tradeoffs that we are forced to make:

  • Managed or unmanaged?
  • If managed, then Google, Amazon or someone else?
  • Relational or non-relational?

posts.html:
Has Apple Fallen Behind in the Design Game?

My opinion here has always been and remains unchanged: Yes and no.

Has Apple Fallen Behind in the Design Game?

My opinion here has always been and remains unchanged: Yes and no.

Good design is the ability to intuit the user’s intent and make use of the user’s intuition.

On one hand, I say no because Apple continues to create some of the highest quality and most functional hardware known to mankind. If we only knew the amount of ingenuity and effort required to build something like the Apple Pencil, our heads would explode. But, they make it look easy. That is amazing.

Yes, because look at the screenshot below and tell me, where I would go to manage my iCloud storage?

Answer: General > Storage & iCloud Usage > iCloud Manage Storage > … smh.

With respect to hardware, no — they are on top of their game. With respect to software, yes, Apple has fallen way behind.

By David Byttow on November 24, 2015.

Secret’s Fundraising

There seem to be misconceptions about Secret’s fundraising. I believe entrepreneurs and investors can and should learn from our story, so…

Secret’s Fundraising


There seem to be misconceptions about Secret’s fundraising. I believe entrepreneurs and investors can and should learn from our story, so this is likely the first of a series of posts to come.

Rejection

Aug — Sept 2013

Back in August, I built a simple web app that let anyone send anonymous messages to anyone else via email or SMS. I was obsessed with how simple the product was, but I required someone with a strong aesthetic and penchant for simplicity to take it to the next level, so I called upon Chrys Bader. He was intrigued and had just left Google, so we set out to build out the iOS product. At the time, I had very little runway to self-fund and so we set out to raise a modest seed round ($500K). We were rejected twice, by the same VC, as they rightly were concerned about the potential downside of this platform. Secret V1 was dead in the water.

Seed

Nov 2013 — Jan 2014

Discouraged and low on funds, I started interviewing at other companies. Chrys and I had a heart-to-heart about my plans, and he convinced me to give it a little more time. I remember us walking around South Park, trying to figure out how we could make anonymity work, without the troubles that 1-to-1 anonymous messaging might bring. I remember, vividly, when Chrys said, “What if the message was broadcasted to everyone you know?” That was a eureka moment. And I felt the address book would be perfect here. From there, Secret V2 was born. 

We built the beta product in no more than two weeks, shared it with friends, and procured a small seed from Garry Tan and Alexis Ohanian. From there, others lined up (Google Ventures, KPCB, Matrix, Index, and a few angels) raising a $1.225M convertible note at a $5.5MM cap followed by a $200K note at an $11MM cap for a total raise of $1.425MM. After two months of beta, we launched the product a month later on January. 

Series A

Feb 2014 — March 2014

Frankly, this time period is a bit of a blur. I couldn’t believe the public and press’ reaction, I certainly wasn’t prepared. I remember, while raising the seed round, telling Chrys that if we could raise again at a $20MM in a year, we’d be doing well. That was our goal. But shortly after launch, VCs and trusted friends began telling us that we could easily raise at a $40MM valuation. We were floored. Google Ventures was the first to sit us down about raising more money, and the rest followed. We had secured a “party round” of $8.6MM at a $40MM valuation, with Google Ventures and KPCB to joint-lead. 

Ready to sign, other term sheets started to flood in, including a couple “blank” term sheets and over 2x the current valuation. I saw two options, A) we could take the smaller offer with the syndicate or B) the higher offer with less dilution from a single investor. 

Perhaps it was my naiveté (this was my first company), but something didn’t feel right about taking that much of other peoples’ money only weeks after launch and with only two employees. We sought the help of a few trusted mentors (who shall remain anonymous) to help us do the right thing. That included talking to Bill Maris of GV and John Doerr of KPCB. Ultimately, and partially out of loyalty to GV, I decided to go with the more modest amount and option A.

Series B

April — Sept 2014

Over these months, we grew the team to over 27 people and experienced exponential international growth (Russia, China, Israel, Brazil, Mexico, Netherlands), at one point we were adding users at a rate of almost 300,000 per day. We scaled, but at a great cost to Google.

I built the original backend for Secret on Google Cloud Platform (App Engine) because I felt I could design a system that “scaled wide” and optimized for availability at the potential cost in dollars. My thinking was, that if we grew too fast, it was better to solve it with cash than with service disruption (i.e., fail whale). That happened, and we didn’t go down, but we had to raise capital to offset the soaring costs, else we’d be out of business by end of August 2014. 

There was a lot of interest in a new round, and given our international growth, I was interested in new investors that could help. The goal as always was to not raise too much and not overly dilute the company and employees. Most of the Series A investors who had pro-rata rights, wanted them. So it wasn’t possible for us to bring in the new, strategic investors at the amount they wanted with respect to the valuation. We managed to “negotiate down” pro-rata rights as far as possible in order to bring in new blood. But eventually, that’s where the idea of doing a “secondary round” was born, a mechanism to bring more investors without diluting the employees, and instead effectively dilute founders by reducing their ownership. This was a trade-off, but the new investors were supportive. We could have continued increasing valuation, or attempting a “rolling close” but we wanted to close quickly given the growth curve. We finalized the terms for the company’s raise of $25MM at a $110MM pre-money valuation. 

Armed with $35MM total money raised by the company and a rockstar talent, we set out to continue scaling the product and growing the team. We were dedicated, optimistic and grateful for all of the diverse and supportive investors around the table. I couldn’t have been more proud of everyone involved.

Unfortunately, sometimes not all goes according to plan, and neither money nor talent alone can guarantee success in the end. We know how this story ends, but how we got there from this point, is a very nuanced and interesting story of twists-and-turns to be told another time.

David Byttow

Building a safe, anonymous community

When we first built Secret, we gave it to our friends and family. Our private beta quickly had over ninety people using it every day. When…

Building a safe, anonymous community


When we first built Secret, we gave it to our friends and family. Our private beta quickly had over ninety people using it every day. When we saw how our friends were sharing, we believed Secret could be something special if not only becausebecause the posts were unlike anything we’d seen on any other social network.

On the other hand, like with any social network, we knew that safety had to be a priority. The two of us had built social networks (e.g., Google Wave, Google+, Photovine) before and understood the importance of privacy, community tools and moderation, and that we’d need to be proactively involved in order to keep Secret safe.

There was still a lot we had to learn. We knew that in order to do a good job, we should be resourceful and not repeat any mistakes that have already been made. We sought out, consulted with, hired and learned from people that have helped build mainstream online anonymous communities, most of which failed. These people included the founders of Formspring, JuicyCampus, Reddit, LikeALittle, TenTwenty, Whisper and many others. The lessons were invaluable.

We truly believe in the importance of honesty and transparency in the world, so we want to share with you everything we’ve learned about building a safe community and how we’ve applied that knowledge to Secret.


Content policy

The first step in protecting a community is defining clear policies. These policies should begin with and reflect the beliefs and values of its founders. We’ve hired and collaborated with experts from Facebook, Google, and Pinterest to define clear, nuanced, and enforceable internal policies around what content we will and won’t allow. This is much harder than we thought, and it took a lot of time to get it to somewhere we were comfortable with.

We don’t allow posts that include or encourage:

  • pornography
  • self-harm
  • bullying or harassment of private individuals
  • threats
  • hate speech
  • graphic content
  • private information (email, phone #s, etc)
  • copyrighted content
  • spam

To learn more, read our Community Guidelines.


Empower the community

The second step is to help the community protect itself. 

We make our community guidelines available to the world and encourage every user, new and old, to read them. This helps members of the community know how they should behave and also helps them recognize bad behavior. 

We make it easy for community members to raise a red flag when they see something against the guidelines. When a user flags a secret, they can choose the reason (Bullying, Self harm, etc). This helps prioritize the secrets that our moderation team reviews so we can react as quickly as possible to more serious violations. Self-harm and bullying are the most highly prioritized flags.


Enforcing the policies

Once you have the policies defined, you must be able to effectively enforce them. Since before the launch of Secret, we’ve been building a sophisticated dashboard that allows a team of moderators to review all secrets that are suspected of being against our policies. 

Secrets are reviewed by moderators when they are flagged by a user or automatically flagged by our system. We automatically flag secrets based on a mix of criteria, including keywords and patterns. This is an area we plan to continue to invest in, because the smarter the system, the faster we can react.

When a secret is taken down, we notifier the people who flagged the secret. This is important so that they know the system is working, and that their participation is important to us.


Moving forward

We care deeply about the safety of people using social networks online. Our policies, community, and platform will be forever evolving and we are committed more than ever to doing everything we can to keep Secret a safe place.


We will continue to make our moderation platform better and faster, grow our trust and safety team, communicate our policies and involve the community.

This morning I read about Yo being hacked. I hadn’t downloaded the app yet, but checking this out was a good enough reason to give it a try.

After about 3 minutes with MITMProxy, I learned 2 things. #1 isn’t a huge deal, but #2… wow.

posts.html:
On Anonymity

And what it means on Secret

On Anonymity

And what it means on Secret

People often ask us whether Secret is truly anonymous. And if it is, why we ask for email address and phone number. Great question! Let’s go deeper.

The answer might depend on what the word “anonymous” means to you. The Merriam-Webster dictionary defines it as:

anonymous: of unknown authorship or origin; not named or identified

In Secret, we never show personally identifiable information to anyone. So yes, posts and comments on Secret are anonymous.

Let’s address a few more points.

Personal Information. Upon signup, we collect your email address, phone number and password and securely store them in our data store. We use this information to match you with people you know via your Contacts so that you can share with one another on Secret. This is part of the magic. Your email address, phone number, password, and who you’re connected to never get shared.

Information Collection. As described in our privacy policy, we log diagnostic information of the service, which is extremely standard for online services. However, we take extra measures to only temporarily store this data and scrub all personally identifiable information from it. Our log retention is no more than 48 hours, as it’s deleted

Plausible deniability. Secret was designed such that you can express any facet of your personality in each post and conversation because each post stands on its own. There are several factors that might suggest a secret belongs to a particular individual. Sometimes, a photo, the way it’s written, or just a simple guess might hint toward a specific person. That said, depending on what you write and which photos you post, it might be possible for people who know you to guess your identity (which is often part of the fun). If there’s something you want to say, but you’d be really unhappy if people suspected you as the author, then it’s probably best not to share it.

Defense through design. We’ve made many design and product decisions to help protect your identity, and we’ll continually evolve. As an example, if someone joins Secret with only a few friends in the system, we will withhold and partially randomize secrets until they reach a minimum number of friends that have shared. The trade-off here is that new users without a critical mass of friends using Secret will not receive a personalized stream in the beginning, but we err on the side of confidentiality to help keep the service safe.

Want to help or have questions regarding privacy or security? Please reach out to security@secret.ly. It’s up to all of us to uphold the privilege of anonymity and free speech.

We hope this helps clear up some of the questions out there. As always, please don’t hesitate to email us at concierge@secret.ly

You should follow us on Twitter. @getsecret

posts.html:
Quitting the Best Job in the World

For the Best Job in the World

Quitting the Best Job in the World

For the Best Job in the World


After publishing Four Steps to Google, Without a Degree the single most asked question I received was “But, why leave?”

I’ve had to answer this question verbally many times. Almost every time, I seem to give a slightly unique answer.

The short answer is, I wanted to see what could happen by applying what I learned at Google out in the real world.

I loved my gig at Google. Unequivocally, I increased my skills and knowledge more in the 4-5 years at Google than anywhere else in my career. And I was fortunate enough to work on several interesting projects at Google, in chronological order:

  1. OpenSocial. Ultimately a failure in my opinion, OpenSocial was Google’s answer to Facebook before it got really serious about social. I helped create OpenSocial Templates, which was a fallout of the template system in the late Google Mashup Editor.
  2. Google App Engine. One of my favorite developer products in existence. Although it can be seen as a toy in comparison to Amazon Web Services or even Heroku, it is a great way to prototype your idea thanks to its single-click, fire-and-forget deployment. I dabbled here in my 20% time, working on bits of backend functionality.
  3. Google Wave. Love it or hate it, Google Wave was undoubtedly an interesting technological experiment. It was one of the most exciting projects at Google in its heyday. I worked on Wave for about a year and a half. Aside, one can point to many reasons why Google Wave ultimately failed, but I believe it comes down to this: There were absolutely no constraints. Engineers were effectively able to implement all sorts of half-baked bells and whistles for the service. Nobody knew how to say no, and we didn’t listen to our customers. In short, there wasn’t really a single thing that the service did extremely well, just a lot of missed opportunities.
  4. Google+. I was an early engineer on Google+, having worked on it for about two years, and tech lead for several projects, including the +1 Button. It is probably the largest (and physically smallest) web application by queries-per-second that I may ever work on. And although I had my hands in many cookie jars, my primary job after the +1 Button was to lead the Profiles and Pages teams. Since leaving Google, I have a soft spot in my heart but also a rather contentious perspective on the product.

#4 was an inflection point for me. It was an amazing team and we moved very fast, probably one of the fastest teams at Google. Relatedly, I respectfully disagree with my close friend and former colleague Dhanji Prasanna in his post, Waving Goodbye, here where he goes on to claim that you can’t move fast at Google with:

Google’s vaunted scalable software infrastructure is obsolete … the software stack on top of it is 10 years old, aging and designed for building search engines and crawlers. And it is well and truly obsolete.

False.

At Google, there are two ways to get things done: The deprecated way, and the not-yet-implemented way. There are always new software stacks being built, many of which are not exactly ready for prime-time, but the wheel is constantly being invented there. What else are you going to do with tens of thousands of very capable engineers? I digress.

But like I said, I left because I wanted to take the wealth of knowledge and experience I accumulated at Google and redirect that toward something else.

For a month, I worked at Obvious Corporation with Ev Williams, Biz Stone, and co. But ultimately, I decided

posts.html:
Shipping Value Solves All Known Problems

Shipping Value Solves All Known Problems


Shipping value to your customers solves almost all known problems, so declaring how often your company and your teams launch should be a first-class citizen in your organization.

Years ago I worked on console video games. Each year the company would launch a new game. So our launch cadence was yearly. We knew this and expected it. If we didn’t, we wouldn’t survive.

Every team should declare how often it launches. The cadence suggests a rough idea how often the team delivers something to its customers. This scales all the way from the company down to a single team and applies to both internal and external customers.

Each team should have a single person that is directly responsible for the team meeting its expectations. And doing both upfront helps to inform a lot of decisions by making the implicit more explicit and keeping the team accountable for delivering.

Allow me to use Google as an example, citing both the company itself and some individual teams (Note: this is fictional and only meant to demonstrate a point).

Google itself launches something every single day. It’s a huge company with many distinct focus areas. It’s Larry Page’s responsibility that it continues to ship value to its customers.

TEAM: Google CADENCE: Daily RESPONSIBILITY: Larry Page

TEAM: Google+ CADENCE: Weekly RESPONSIBILITY: Vic Gundotra

Notice that this is hierarchical. Larry is responsible for Google shipping something to it’s users on a daily basis. Vic ensures that Google+ maintains some form of visible launch at least on a weekly basis.

Taking this further, there are individual teams within Google+, some responsible for photos and others for mobile, which have different cadences (notably, mobile applications may publish new releases far less often than the web application launches new features).

This system works for any team in your company.

TEAM: Legal CADENCE: Monthly RESPONSIBILITY: Lawyer Cat

Legal may be responsible for things like delivering internal processes for the company like a patent filing process.

As for cadences, I suggest starting with daily, weekly, monthly and quarterly. Quarterly may seem like a long time, but consider teams such as Hardware (which have long lead times) or Research and Development divisions.

Do this for your entire organization. Publish the results and change it as needed.
